Item 1. Business.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 1. Business section in bullet points:

• ZS was incorporated in 2007.
• The company predicted that traditional perimeter security approaches would prove to be inadequate in protecting users and data due to rapid cloud adoption and increasing workforce mobility.
• Enterprise applications are rapidly moving to the cloud, with organizations adopting new external software as a service (SaaS) applications for critical business functions.
• Users now expect to be able to seamlessly access applications and data from any device, anywhere in the world.
• The company believes that securing the corporate network is becoming increasingly irrelevant in a cloud and mobile-first world.

Item 1A. Risk Factors.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Item 1A. Risk Factors section of ZS's Annual Report on Form 10-K in bullet points:

• ZS has a history of annual net losses and may not be able to achieve or sustain profitability in the future.
• The company expects to incur annual net losses for the foreseeable future, having incurred net losses in all annual periods since its inception.
• The market price of ZS's common stock could decline if the occurrence of any events or developments described in this section or additional risks and uncertainties not presently known to the company occur.
• If organizations do not adopt ZS's cloud platform, the company's ability to grow its business and operating results may be adversely affected.
• The company faces intense and increasing competition, which could lead to a loss of market share to competitors.
• ZS has experienced rapid revenue growth in recent periods, but this may not be indicative of future performance.
• The company's operating results may fluctuate significantly, making it difficult to predict future results.
• If the delivery of ZS's services to customers is interrupted or delayed, the business would suffer.
• The actual or perceived failure of ZS's cloud platform to block malware or prevent a security breach could harm the company's reputation and business.

Item 1C. Cybersecurity.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - Item 1C. Cybersecurity section in bullet points:

• The company's platform was built leveraging guidance from leading industry frameworks to effectively manage and mitigate cybersecurity risks.
• The audit committee of the board of directors and the internal security committee oversee the company's rigorous risk management processes, which include data privacy, product security, and information security.
• The internal security committee is led by the chief security officer and includes representatives from various departments, including security team, IT, engineering, enterprise risk, product management, cloud operations, legal, and compliance teams.
• The internal security committee has over 150 certified and experienced cybersecurity professionals and information security managers with many years of experience across technology sub-specialties.
• The company's in-house global threat research team, Zscaler ThreatLabZ, consists of more than 150 security experts who work to identify and prevent emerging threats using malware reverse engineering, behavior analytics, data science, and AI.
• The internal security teams and external cybersecurity auditors regularly evaluate the company's products by performing regular penetration tests and risk assessments to identify potential vulnerabilities.
• The company regularly reviews its cybersecurity policies, standards, and procedures in response to changes in the threat landscape and legal and regulatory developments.

Item 2. Properties.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 2. Properties section in bullet points:

• Our corporate headquarters are located in San Jose, California.
• We lease approximately 172,000 square feet of space under a sublease agreement that expires in 2026.
• We maintain offices elsewhere in the United States and internationally, including in Asia, Europe, and the Middle East.
• We lease all of our facilities and do not own any real property.

Item 5. Market for Registrant's Common E.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 5. Market for Registrant's Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities section in bullet points:

• Our common stock has been listed on The Nasdaq Global Select Market under the ticker symbol "ZS" since March 16, 2018.
• As of July 31, 2024, we had 51 holders of record of our common stock.
• We have never declared or paid cash dividends on our common stock and currently intend to retain all available funds for use in the operation of our business.
• The actual number of stockholders is greater than the number of record holders due to beneficial owners whose shares are held in street name by brokers and other nominees.
• As of July 31, 2024, there were no recent sales of unregistered equity securities, use of proceeds, or issuer purchases of equity securities.

Item 7. Management’s Discussion and Anal.summary:
Here are the key facts from the Management's Discussion and Analysis section in bullet points:

• Zscaler was incorporated in 2007.
• The company's fiscal year ends on July 31, with fiscal quarters ending on October 31, January 31, April 30, and July 31.
• Fiscal years 2024, 2023, and 2022 ended with revenues of $2,167.8 million, $1,617.0 million, and $1,090.9 million, respectively.
• The company has incurred net losses in all annual periods since its inception, with net losses of $57.7 million, $202.3 million, and $390.3 million for fiscal 2024, 2023, and 2022, respectively.
• As of July 31, 2024, Zscaler had expanded operations to over 8,650 customers across major industries, with users in over 185 countries.
• Approximately 35% of the Forbes Global 2000 rely on Zscaler for digital transformation support as of July 31, 2024.

Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Di.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk section, formatted as bullet points:

• As of July 31, 2024, ZS had cash, cash equivalents, and short-term investments totaling $2,409.7 million.

• The effect of a hypothetical 100 basis point change in interest rates would have changed the fair value of ZS's available-for-sale securities by $10.0 million as of July 31, 2024.

• ZS uses interest rate swaps to economically convert certain fixed interest rate Notes to floating interest rates, with changes in fair value offsetting changes in market value due to benchmark interest rate movements.

• In June 2020, ZS issued Convertible Senior Notes with an aggregate principal amount of $1,150.0 million.

• The fair value of the Notes is exposed to interest rate risk and fluctuates when the market price of ZS's common stock fluctuates.

• As of July 31, 2024, the fair value of the Notes was determined based on the quoted bid price of the Notes in an over-the-counter market on the last trading day of the reporting period.

Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplem.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data section in bullet points:

• The auditor's opinion is that the consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Zscaler, Inc. as of July 31, 2024 and 2023, and the results of its operations and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended July 31, 2024.
• The auditor's opinion is also that the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of July 31, 2024.
• The Company changed the manner in which it accounts for convertible senior notes as of August 1, 2022.
• The auditor conducted their audits in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement and effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained.

Item 9A. Controls and Procedures.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 9A. Controls and Procedures section in bullet points:

• As of July 31, 2024, ZS's management concluded that its disclosure controls and procedures were effective at the reasonable assurance level.
• The company's internal control over financial reporting was effective as of July 31, 2024, based on an evaluation conducted by management using the Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
• PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm, audited the effectiveness of ZS's internal control over financial reporting as of July 31, 2024.
• Airgap and Avalor, acquired on April 12, 2024, and March 8, 2024, respectively, were excluded from management's evaluation of internal control over financial reporting due to their small size (collectively representing approximately 0.4% and 0.1%, respectively, of the related consolidated financial statement amounts).
• There was no change in ZS's internal control over financial reporting identified during the fiscal quarter ended July 31, 2024 that has materially affected or is reasonably likely to affect its internal control over financial reporting.
• Management believes that disclosure controls and procedures and internal control over financial reporting are designed to provide reasonable assurance of achieving their objectives but acknowledges that no control system can provide absolute assurance against errors and fraud.

Item 9B. Other Information.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 9B. Other Information section in bullet points:

• Robert Schlossman, ZS's chief legal officer and secretary, adopted a Rule 10b5-1 trading arrangement on June 29, 2024.
• The trading arrangement allows for the sale of up to 24,793 shares of common stock.
• The arrangement also covers up to 100% of outstanding RSUs and PSUs, with certain exceptions for tax withholding obligations.
• The duration of the trading arrangement is until September 25, 2025, or earlier if all transactions are completed.

Item 10. Directors, Executive Officers a.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - Item 10. Directors, Executive Officers and Corporate Governance in bullet points:

• The ZS company has adopted a code of business conduct and ethics (Code of Conduct) that applies to all employees, executive officers, and directors.
• The full text of the Code of Conduct is available on the company's website at ir.zscaler.com.
• The nominating and corporate governance committee of the board of directors is responsible for overseeing the Code of Conduct.
• Any waivers of the Code of Conduct must be approved by the nominating and corporate governance committee of the board of directors.
• Amendments to the Code of Conduct will be disclosed on the company's website, as required by applicable law or The Nasdaq Global Market listing standards.

Item 15. Exhibits, Financial Statement S.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART IV - Item 15. Exhibits, Financial Statement Schedule in bullet points:

• The Index to Financial Statements can be found in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
• All financial statement schedules have been omitted due to not being required or applicable.
• Certain portions of Exhibit 15 have been omitted as the information is deemed non-material and competitively harmful if disclosed.
• The certifications in Exhibit 32.1 are deemed to accompany this report, but will not be considered "filed" under Section 18 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
